pages.title: About
pages.description: A boutique Jekyll theme for hackers, nerds, and academics, with a focus on personal sites that are meant to impress.
pages.content:
Hydejack

A boutique Jekyll theme for hackers, nerds, and academics.


  Hydejack
  A Personal Site That Won’t Disappear
  A Free Blogging Theme
  An Impressive Portfolio
  A Printable Resume
  Just Markdown
  Just Markup
  Syntax Highlighting
  Beautiful Math
  Features
  Download
  Get It Now




Hydejack’s cover page on a variety of screen sizes.

Hydejack is a boutique Jekyll theme for hackers, nerds, and academics, with a focus on personal sites that are meant to impress.

It includes a blog that is suitable for both prose and technical documentation, a portfolio to showcase your projects, and a resume template that looks amazing on the web and in print.


  Your complete presence on the web — A blog, portfolio, and resume.


A Personal Site That Won’t Disappear

Hydejack is 100% built on Open Source software, and is Open Source itself, save for parts of the PRO version. The PRO version is a one-time payment that gives you the right to use it forever.

Hydejack is all static sites. HTML. All you need is a web server — any web server — to have a professional web presence that lasts a lifetime.

A Free Blogging Theme
Hydejack started out as a free blogging theme for Jekyll — and continues to be so.



An Impressive Portfolio
A portfolio that’s guaranteed to be impressive — no matter what you put into it.



A Printable Resume
Get a resume that’s consistent across the board — whether it’s on the web, mobile, print, or PDF.



Front and center page of a print resume generated by Hydejack.

Just Markdown
Write all content with Markdown. Hydejack gives you additional CSS classes to stylize your content, without losing compatibility with other Jekyll themes.

Just Markup
Hydejack boasts a plethora of modern JavaScript, but make no mistake: It’s still a plain old web page at its core. It works without JavaScript and you can even view it in a text-based browser like w3m:



The Hydejack blog, as seen by the text browser w3m.

Syntax Highlighting
Hydejack features syntax highlighting, powered by Rouge.

<!-- file: `_includes/my-body.html` -->
<script type="module">
  document.querySelector("hy-push-state").addEventListener("hy-push-state-load", () => {
    const supportsCodeHighlights = false; // TBD!!
  });
</script>


Code blocks can have a filename and a caption.

Beautiful Math
They say math is beautiful — and with Hydejack’s math support it’s guaranteed to also look beautiful:

ϕ(x,y)=ϕ(∑i=1nxiei,∑j=1nyjej)=∑i=1n∑j=1nxiyjϕ(ei,ej)=(x1,…,xn)(ϕ(e1,e1)⋯ϕ(e1,en)⋮⋱⋮ϕ(en,e1)⋯ϕ(en,en))(y1⋮yn)\begin{aligned}
  \phi(x,y) &= \phi \left(\sum_{i=1}^n x_ie_i, \sum_{j=1}^n y_je_j \right) \\[2em]
            &= \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n x_i y_j \phi(e_i, e_j)            \\[2em]
            &= (x_1, \ldots, x_n)
               \left(\begin{array}{ccc}
                 \phi(e_1, e_1)  & \cdots & \phi(e_1, e_n) \\
                 \vdots          & \ddots & \vdots         \\
                 \phi(e_n, e_1)  & \cdots & \phi(e_n, e_n)
               \end{array}\right)
               \left(\begin{array}{c}
                 y_1    \\
                 \vdots \\
                 y_n
               \end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}ϕ(x,y)​=ϕ(i=1∑n​xi​ei​,j=1∑n​yj​ej​)=i=1∑n​j=1∑n​xi​yj​ϕ(ei​,ej​)=(x1​,…,xn​)​ϕ(e1​,e1​)⋮ϕ(en​,e1​)​⋯⋱⋯​ϕ(e1​,en​)⋮ϕ(en​,en​)​​​y1​⋮yn​​​​

Hydejack uses KaTeX to efficiently render math.

Features

An incomplete list of features included in all versions of Hydejack:


  Responsive layout with unique design features for every screen size
  Cover Pages for a stunning first impression.
  Customizable sidebar and touch-enabled drawer menu
  Single Page Web App-style page loading
  Advanced FLIP animations, inspired by Material Design
  Good Google PageSpeed Score1
  Syntax highlighting, powered by Rouge
  LaTeX math blocks, rendered with ether KaTeX or MathJax at your choice
  Soft-coded labels: Change wording or translate to other languages via a single file
  Support for categories and tags
  Author section below each article and support for multiple authors
  Built-in icons for many social networks
  Simple and semantic HTML + Structured Data
  Works with GitHub Pages out of the box2


Download

There are two versions of Hydejack: The Free Version includes basic blogging functionality and most of Hydejack’s Features, such as dynamic page loading and advanced animations.

The PRO Version includes additional features for professionals, such as a portfolio, resume, Dark Mode, Forms, Built-In Search and customizable cookie banners.

The table below shows what’s included in each version:

Get It Now

Use the the form below to purchase Hydejack PRO:

      Some limitations apply, most notably the need to use use MathJax instead of KaTeX for math block rendering. ↩︎
    
    
      Large screens (> 1664px width) only. ↩︎

pages.title: Software Architecture Projects
pages.description: For 20+ years I have worked on projects in corporate environments as a Senior Solution Architect in IT Service Management.In the last 10+ years I have also worked as Chief Technology Officer and Chief Product Officer on various Startups, often in the Blockchain space.  (Some project pages are still missing, I will be adding them, and more details, soon.)

documents.title: iBitcoin
documents.content:
I started mining Bitcoin in 2010, and wanted to see my mining statistics on my phone whilst away.
We developed an app with Mining Stats, Market Data, Network Data and for a brief time wallet functionality 
via Exchange API calls. We were in Top 10 Finance apps for weeks until Apple removed our app from the AppStore.
Much of the development is informed from my experience of using it myself, creating a tight feedback loop.

documents.title: Leesplankje
documents.content:
The concept was based on an old Dutch method for learning how to read, using a wooden board and blocks with letters.
We turned that into a digital version, using your fingers to drag letters. And when you touched a letter, you heard the proper pronounciation (in my Mom’s voice 😁).




It was in the Top 10 Educational Apps (AppStore), and was acquired by Noordhoff (largest Dutch educational publisher).

documents.title: AstroWeather
documents.content:
Back in 2011, there were a number of weather apps for iPhone, but not many that were developed with Astronomers in mind.
This app has helped me estimate many nights whether or not to go out with my telescope.
Out of a personal need and a lack of options, AstroWeather was born and lived for a few years on the AppStore.

documents.title: Mpowa
documents.content: A tokenized, zero-point energy ecosystem to provide decentralized electricity to communities and households.

documents.title: Karakoram
documents.content:
I was part of the project’s 3rd phase (which was postponed due to the pandemic) in Karakoram Mountains (Pakistan), 
and developed a prototype Early Warning System for Glacial Lake Outburst Floods (GLOFs), based on Mesh Networking 
and low-cost hardware. 




A concept mockup of the technical prototype (Ralph Reijs - 2020)



Outdoor Journal - Oliver Foster (2020)



Photo Credit: Tim Taylor (2018)

documents.title: Applied Universal Mathematics
documents.content:
Based on Advanced Numbers Theory, together with a team, I designed and developed a Backtester to mathematically 
find Harmonic Points in any and all data, from finance to sunspots. Heavily redacted due to NDA. 




It all started with my favorite book, written by Anthony Morris.



Harmonic Points in Historic Financial Data



Harmonic Points in Historical Public Data



Harmonic Points in Historical Public Data



Backtester - Chart Mode



Backtester - Animated



Backtester - Closed Trades

documents.content:
I started a company that helps individuals achieve self-custody over their Bitcoin, and helps companies 
integrate Bitcoin (Lightning). The company has not launched yet, it is still a work in progress.

documents.title: Hacking
documents.content:
I’ve been tinkering, crafting and (generally trying to break stuff to learn how it works) since I was a kid.
When I got into computers and electronics (around age 10, in 1990) I was instantly hooked on the challenge of manipulating the behaviour of electronic systems.
#HackThePlanet!



A custom-built Jasager (initial project of the Wifi Pineapple) with MITM router



PlayStation Vita hacking with HENkaku 変革 (2015)



WiFi Hacking with Wemos D1 Mini (2015)



At Hackerspace ‘Technologia Incognita’ (2011)



Lock Picking (2018)



WiFi Pineapple on OpenWRT / BusyBox (2012)



OpenWRT on Arduino Yún (2012)



WiFi PenTesting Kit (2012)



iLantern Concept [300 Programmable LEDs] (2012)



Ethereum War Dialer</a>



Copyright Ralph Reijs (2015)



Observe. Hack. Make.  (2013)



Technologia Incognita Hackerspace (2017)

documents.title: Instatunnel
documents.content:
Instatunnel was a concept around PrePaid VPN Bandwidth with zero logging. Each card gave a specific amount of guaranteed snoop-proof bandwidth. The prepaid cards were to be sold at Airports, Hotels, Supermarkets.




Prepaid Cards (2013)



Beta Portal (2013)



Status Page (2013)

documents.title: Cloudlynx
documents.content:
We were the first to have a fully Pharma-compliant cloud network infrastructure with record network speeds. I was redesigning the OpenStack Horizon dashboard with an extremely userfriendly UI/UX in Python and Django.




Cloudlynx (2015)



Cloudlynx (2015)



Cloudlynx (2015)



Cloudlynx (2015)

documents.title: Pillar
documents.content:
Founding Team Member, started as a tech generalist. After some months, we did a succesful ICO and raised $27M in 60h.
I fell in love with the original idea of the Personal Data Locker and decided I wanted to help build it.
During the ICO / Token Sale I handled the livestream broadcast and technical overlays / integrations. After the first Unconference, I took position as Head of IT Security and Infrastructure.





The original PDL Concept Video (2016)



The Launch Video (2017)



Pillar’s second logo (2017)



Pillar Unconference (Slovakia, 2017)



Pillar Community @ Rocket.Chat (2017)



Pillar Unconference (Slovakia, 2017)



Pillar Office (London, 2018)



 New Kids On The Blockchain (Lithuania, 2018)

documents.title: WarDial
documents.content:
Named after ‘War dialing’ from the 80s, this was a little Proof of Concept script to ‘hack’ Ethereum wallets by generating random wallet seeds and checking whether they have a balance.
If a wallet with balance higher than 0 ETH was found, an alert would be sent through a Telegram bot.




The WarDial script being executed (2018)



The WarDial script being executed (2018)



214,000+ wallets had been checked (2018)



Example of generated wallets (2018)



Telegram bot for alerts (2018)

documents.title: IT Service Management
documents.content:
For more than 20 years, I have worked at large international organisations as a Senior Solution Architect for IT Service Management software. My clients are usually based in Europe, North America and the Middle East. Banks, Insurance companies, Pharmaceutical companies, Petrochemical companies, usually organisations with a 100.000 employees or more.

My Resonsibilities:

  Stakeholder Meetings
  Consolidation of functional and technical requirements
  Advisory to the Board / Process Owners
  Design of technical solution
  User Interface design
  Implementation of solution according to company policy and SDLC
  Infrastructure analysis and stress-tests
  Security analysis & penetration tests
  Administrator and End-User Documentation
  Business Reporting
  Automation & Integration
  Support and Training of employees / end-users


ITIL Processes:

  Service Management
  Incident Management
  Problem Management
  Change Management
  Release Management
  Request Management
  Asset Management
  Knowledge Management
  Configuration Management
  Service Level Management


Clients


    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
  




I started in 1998 with Peregrine Systems ServiceCenter 3. The software was originally called PNMS (Problem Network Management System) for MVS / 3270 systems, and the GUI was based on “lines” as to maintain backward compatibility with text-based UIs.



Peregrine Systems ServiceCenter v6 (2002)

In 2005, HP acquired Peregrine Systems and made their various software products a part of the HP OpenView portfolio. ServiceCenter was then called ServiceManager, and it received a number of big updates that gave it less of a text-based GUI feeling.



HP ServiceManager v7 (2007)

From around 2011, the ServiceNow platform (created by the former CTO of Peregrine Systems) had taken of a large share of the corporate IT Service Management market, and many corporations were making the switch.



ServiceNow (2015)

documents.title: Wardial
documents.content:
Named after ‘War dialing’ from the 80s, this was a little Proof of Concept script to ‘hack’ Ethereum wallets by generating random wallet seeds and checking whether they have a balance. Basically “discovering existing wallets”.
If a wallet with balance higher than 0 ETH was found, an alert would be sent through a Telegram bot.




The WarDial script being executed (2018)



The WarDial script being executed (2018)



214,000+ wallets had been checked (2018)



Example of generated wallets (2018)



Telegram bot for alerts (2018)

documents.title: JuiceR
documents.content:
A fully automated Tumbling / Mixing platform for the Ethereum blockchain. Worked for both ETH as well ERC20 tokens.
It was a very fun project, and it taught me a lot about blockchain development.
Successfully used on Main Net with ETH and millions of tokens
